review.title: Collaborative ontology sharing and editing
review.abstract: This article first lists reasons why - in the long term or when creating a new knowledge base (KB) for general knowledge sharing purposes - collaboratively building a well-organized KB does/can provide more possibilities, with on the whole no more costs, than the mainstream approach where knowledge creation and re-use involves searching, merging and creating (semi-)independent (relatively small) ontologies or semi-formal documents. The article lists elements required to achieve this and describes the main one: a KB editing protocol that keeps the KB free of automatically/manually detected inconsistencies while not forcing them to discuss or agree on terminology and beliefs nor requiring a selection committee.

metadata.title: COLLABORATIVE KNOWLEDGE SHARING AND EDITING

sections.text: This article first lists reasons why - in the long run or when creating a new Knowledge Base (KB) for general knowledge exchange purposes - the collaborative construction of a well-organized KB offers more possibilities without, by and large, incurring more costs than the mainstream approach, in which the creation and reuse of knowledge involves (semi-) independent (relatively small) ontologies or semi-formal documents. It lists the elements required for this and describes the most important: a KB processing protocol that keeps the KB free from automatically / manually detected inconsistencies, but does not force it to discuss or agree on terminology and beliefs, nor requires a selection committee.KEYWORDSKnowledge Sharing, Integration, Retrieal and Evaluation.

sections.heading: 6. CONCLUSION
sections.text: This article aims first of all to show that a cbwoKB is technically and socially possible. To this end, a protocol has been presented in the fourth (and most important) part of this article, which makes it possible to encourage people to gradually integrate their knowledge into a well-organized (formal or semi-formal) KB without having to agree on terminology or beliefs. As I said, it seems that all other knowledge-based cooperation protocols currently based on the comparison or integration of whole KB are not based on the comparison and lossless integration of all their objects into a KB. Other elements required for a cbwoKB-2 also implement the research results: expressive and normalizing notations, methodological guidance, a large general ontology, and an initial cbwoKB core for the application domain of the intended cbwoKB.
